captions.text:
History has a long and rich tradition of apocalyptic
predictions – all of which were wrong – yet

some people still think that this time ’round
in 2012 is the real deal.

Why 2012?
Because of ancient Mayan calendars. Obviously.

Mayan calendars not only recorded the days
and years, but also longer cycles of about

5 Millennia.
So they could easily make calendars that went

1,000s of years into the future. But, of course,
1,000s of years in the future from 1,000s

of years ago brings us to current times when
the Mayan calendars stop in 2012.

Modern new-agey people decided that the wise
Mayans stopped making calendars because they

knew when the world would end.
And because new agers are happy – though

scientifically illiterate – people their
vision of 2012 was a great spiritual awakening

or world reboot or other hippy-consciousness-expanding
nonsense that the Mayans, who spent time puling

strings of thorns through peoples’ tongue,
probably didn’t have in mind.

To a normal person the thought that: calendar
finishes therefore end of the world is an

odd conclusion to draw.
After all, the amount of time in the Universe

is infinite and the amount of stone is limited.
So, at some point the Mayans had to stop carving

calendars.
But never mind.

What should have stayed a fringe belief turned
into mass hysteria with the 2012 disaster

movie that swept the academy awards and the
numerous emmy-nominated apocalypse documentaries

on
::sigh::

The History Channel.
What happened to you guys?

Anyway. After this NASA became so inundated
with questions that they had to take time

away from their busy robot building, frontier
pushing, knowledge expanding, civilization

inspiring schedule, to write a webpage explaining
that no, a human-sacrificing, stone-age society

with neither wheels to pull carts nor glass
to make telescopes, didn’t know more about

science at the dawn of history than real scientists
do today.

But the parade of crazy marched on anyway
making wilder and wilder predictions for Earth

including:
• Geomagnetic Reversal (a process that unfolds

on a geologic timescale, not a single day)
• A collision with mysterious Planet X (That

no astronomers have found)
• A local star going supernova (Despite

there being no such candidates)
• An Alien Invasion (Which is ludicrous

on the face of it… or is it?)
• And a galactic synchronization beam, whatever

the hell that is.
A sane person, at this point, would wonder

how the Mayans were able to predict astro-physical
anomalies thousands of years in advance and

millions of miles away yet didn’t foresee
the Spanish coming across the Atlantic.

And that’s because the Mayans never predicted
apocalypse. The only people to claim the Mayans

knew about the end of the world were distinctly
not Mayans.�

comments.text:
The amount of stone is not limited. Minecraft is an infinitely developed 
world. meaning no matter how far I walk in any direction. if I were to dig 
under the dirt I would find stone. Say I walked so far that my computer 
couldn't process the memory required for the world. never fear! By digging 
one block down and four blocks horizontal. Then digging one extra block 
down a single block from either the first or the last block dug. Then 
dumping a water source block on the shorter end and a lava source block on 
the longer end, you've managed to create an infinite source of stone.﻿

comments.text:
Here's the real story - the Mayan long count calendar is composed of 20 
periods called baktuns. Each baktun is a period of exactly 144,000 days ( 
approximately 394 years and 2 months). The first baktun  began on August 
13, 3113 B.C. The 13th baktun ended on December 21, 2012. The final (20th) 
baktun does not end (thus the world will not end, according to the mayans) 
until October 13, 4772 A.D. So party on, folks....we still have 2,757 years 
to go!﻿

comments.author: Amoux Johnson

comments.text:
There is no Mayan Calender in the video, the stone carving you see is the 
Aztec Stone of the Fifth Sun, usually referred to (with limited accuracy) 
as the Aztec Calender. It's on display at the National Museum of 
Anthropology in Mexico City. So, passing that iconic stone off as Mayan is 
over 1000 miles and 500 years off!!! 

I assume the educated among you know that the Mayans have no doomsday 
prediction in their religion and they had several ancient calenders that 
are vague on dating. The doomsday nonsense was invented by new age religion 
cultists in the US who know nothing about Mayan culture.

Knowing how naive Americans can be to fall for such nonsense, Mayan tour 
operators in the Yucatan used this new age superstition as part of their 
advertising for a while, doubtless laughing at the stupidity of it all. ﻿

comments.author: RAϟΣℜ ΣLΣCTR0Π

comments.text:
Look, I have a degree in computer science and I've been working on Unix and 
Linux-based network infrastructure for many years. What you must mean by 
"computer geek" is a basement dwelling, fantasy living, Otaku game nerd 
that doesn't actually understand computers (may have some skills), but 
rather lives a reclusive lifestyle that lends itself to computers. I was 
talking about computer/communications scientists with foundational 
knowledge of computers, people who know what POSIX is, people who have 
built an ALU from NPN transistors, and people who know the problem between 
P and NP. I'm talking about scholars, not dungeon crawling script kiddies. 
To be more concise, let me rephrase my previous statement: the vast 
majority of *people who actually understood computers*  were not hysterical 
about the Y2K bug. Let me put it another way: if you were a REAL tech pro 
in 2000, the Y2K bug was a JOB OPPORTUNITY.
comments.author: No Fullname

comments.text:
+No Fullname You must be very young. Yes, the tech geeks certainly did and 
talked about it a great deal. It was really about superstition due to the 
millennium, and computers were used to update the panic of the year 1000. 
It's like updating witch scares with space aliens. 

In case you haven't noticed, computer geeks are very superstitious and 
often believe in conspiracy theories.
comments.author: Hanno the Phoenician

comments.text:
+Hanno the Phoenician +Yemto First of all, computer nerds didn't fall for 
the Y2K hysteria, it was the news media and the general public. The nerds 
knew it was an easy fix. The 2038 changeover will go back to January 1, 
1970, not 1901. It's a quick fix, but it will cause a measurable amount of 
unnecessary panic again if we wait until the last minute (people don't 
learn). Also want to add: it's not just a matter of moving to a 64-bit 
system, all kernels need to be re-written to use a 64-bit integer for its 
epoch. Still, not that difficult.
